cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Which comedy written by Johnny Speight which first aired in 1965, featured a fervent West Ham supporter?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To answer the question, we need to identify the comedy written by Johnny Speight that first aired in 1965 and features a fervent West Ham supporter. Johnny Speight is known for creating characters that often reflect social issues and working-class life in Britain. One of his most famous works is "Till Death Us Do Part," which premiered in 1965. The main character, Alf Garnett, is a staunch supporter of West Ham United, which aligns with the description given in the question.

Answer:
"Till Death Us Do Part"

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Which comedy written by Johnny Speight which first aired in 1965, featured a fervent West Ham supporter?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['A Ham in a Role is a Looney Tunes short starring the Goofy Gophers along with an unnamed dog who is based on stage/film actor John Barrymore. The cartoon was directed by Robert McKimson. It was released by Warner Bros. Pictures on December 13, 1949, but some sources list the release date as December 31, 1949. The cartoon draws heavily from the works of William Shakespeare, with its gags relying on literal interpretations of lines from "Hamlet", "Julius Caesar", "Richard III", and "Romeo and Juliet".\n', 'Nick Offerman: American Ham is a 2014 American stand-up comedy film, directed by Jordan Vogt-Roberts. It is written by American actor, writer, and carpenter, Nick Offerman. The film had its world premiere at 2014 Sundance Film Festival on January 23, 2014.\n', 'When the Ham Turned is a 1914 American comedy film featuring Oliver Hardy.\n', 'Following his service, he performed in summer stock in Texas and then moved to New York City, where he was given his first film role - the Academy Award-nominated short subject "The Cliffdwellers". Hampton\'s next role came as the lead character in a May 1963 "Gunsmoke" episode entitled "Jeb", featuring his friend and series regular Burt Reynolds.\n', "Owens coauthored Langston Hughes's Little Ham: A Harlem Jazzical with Judd Woldin in 2003. The book was published by Samuel French, Inc and performed as a musical Off Broadway. Langston Hughes's Little Ham: A Harlem Jazzical Is set in the heyday of the 1930s Harlem Renaissance. The story follows Hamlet Hitchcock Jones, known as Little Ham, as he prevents a downtown mob from taking over the Harlem numbers racket. Hughes's Little Ham: A Harlem Jazzical Arranger Luther Henderson was nominated for 2003 Drama Desk Award, Outstanding Orchestrations.\n", 'Hoadly was fond of the stage, and was author of "The Suspicious Husband", a comedy, which was first acted at Covent Garden Theatre on 12 February 1747. David Garrick wrote a prologue for it, and acted the part of Ranger. It hit the popular taste, was often repeated on the stage, and was published in 1747 with a dedication to the king. The critics Samuel Foote and John Genest also praised it. A farce by Charles Macklin, "The Suspicious Husband Criticized", was produced at Drury Lane on 24 March 1747.\n', '"The Radio Ham" is an episode from the comedy series "Hancock", the final BBC series featuring British comedian Tony Hancock. First transmitted on 9 June 1961, the show was written by Ray Galton and Alan Simpson, and was produced by Duncan Wood. The title is a retronym. \n', 'Johnny Speight (2 June 1920 – 5 July 1998) was an English television scriptwriter of many classic British sitcoms.\n', '"The Hampsterdance Song" is a song by Hampton the Hampster. It was released in July 2000 as a single. It was produced by The Boomtang Boys, who used a sped-up hook from the Roger Miller song "Whistle Stop", notably featured in Disney\'s 1973 film "Robin Hood".\n', 'Arthur Hambling (14 March 1888 – 6 December 1952) was a British actor, on stage from 1912, and best known for appearances in the films "Henry V" (1944) and "The Lavender Hill Mob" (1951).\n']

"Till Death Us Do Part"

question_info.question: Which comedy written by Johnny Speight which first aired in 1965, featured a fervent West Ham supporter?
passages:
A Ham in a Role is a Looney Tunes short starring the Goofy Gophers along with an unnamed dog who is based on stage/film actor John Barrymore. The cartoon was directed by Robert McKimson. It was released by Warner Bros. Pictures on December 13, 1949, but some sources list the release date as December 31, 1949. The cartoon draws heavily from the works of William Shakespeare, with its gags relying on literal interpretations of lines from "Hamlet", "Julius Caesar", "Richard III", and "Romeo and Juliet".
Nick Offerman: American Ham is a 2014 American stand-up comedy film, directed by Jordan Vogt-Roberts. It is written by American actor, writer, and carpenter, Nick Offerman. The film had its world premiere at 2014 Sundance Film Festival on January 23, 2014.
When the Ham Turned is a 1914 American comedy film featuring Oliver Hardy.
Following his service, he performed in summer stock in Texas and then moved to New York City, where he was given his first film role - the Academy Award-nominated short subject "The Cliffdwellers". Hampton's next role came as the lead character in a May 1963 "Gunsmoke" episode entitled "Jeb", featuring his friend and series regular Burt Reynolds.
Owens coauthored Langston Hughes's Little Ham: A Harlem Jazzical with Judd Woldin in 2003. The book was published by Samuel French, Inc and performed as a musical Off Broadway. Langston Hughes's Little Ham: A Harlem Jazzical Is set in the heyday of the 1930s Harlem Renaissance. The story follows Hamlet Hitchcock Jones, known as Little Ham, as he prevents a downtown mob from taking over the Harlem numbers racket. Hughes's Little Ham: A Harlem Jazzical Arranger Luther Henderson was nominated for 2003 Drama Desk Award, Outstanding Orchestrations.
Hoadly was fond of the stage, and was author of "The Suspicious Husband", a comedy, which was first acted at Covent Garden Theatre on 12 February 1747. David Garrick wrote a prologue for it, and acted the part of Ranger. It hit the popular taste, was often repeated on the stage, and was published in 1747 with a dedication to the king. The critics Samuel Foote and John Genest also praised it. A farce by Charles Macklin, "The Suspicious Husband Criticized", was produced at Drury Lane on 24 March 1747.
"The Radio Ham" is an episode from the comedy series "Hancock", the final BBC series featuring British comedian Tony Hancock. First transmitted on 9 June 1961, the show was written by Ray Galton and Alan Simpson, and was produced by Duncan Wood. The title is a retronym. 
Johnny Speight (2 June 1920 – 5 July 1998) was an English television scriptwriter of many classic British sitcoms.
"The Hampsterdance Song" is a song by Hampton the Hampster. It was released in July 2000 as a single. It was produced by The Boomtang Boys, who used a sped-up hook from the Roger Miller song "Whistle Stop", notably featured in Disney's 1973 film "Robin Hood".
Arthur Hambling (14 March 1888 – 6 December 1952) was a British actor, on stage from 1912, and best known for appearances in the films "Henry V" (1944) and "The Lavender Hill Mob" (1951).
